Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Affiliative Social Relationships and Immune Function in Primates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Most primates are social species, and sociality comes with both benefits and costs. This doctoral dissertation project will assess underlying mechanisms by which social bonds shape well-being in primates. The investigator will study the interaction of behavior, hormones, immune function, and pathogens, to see whether stronger social bonds are associated with better immune function and lower physiological stress. The findings from this study will provide a comparative model for understanding sociality in our own species. The project will also further science education outreach and student training, primate conservation efforts, and development of international collaborations.

This project will investigate social buffering in wild chimpanzees at Ngogo, Kibale National Park, Uganda - the largest wild chimpanzee community ever studied. To assess the physiological and immunological correlates of social bonds, the investigators will measure dyadic bond strength, glucocorticoids (which reflect physiological reactions to stress and, when chronically elevated, impair immune function), oxytocin (a nonapeptide correlated with social bonding that may also attenuate glucocorticoid secretion), markers of immune activation (i.e., urinary neopterin and body temperature), and the presence of pathogenic infection. The investigators will noninvasively collect behavioral observations, urine, and feces from 50 adult and adolescent chimpanzees. Hormones and immune biomarkers will then be analyzed and infectious agents will be sequenced.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Social relationships may impact health through the secretion of hormones that modify both behavior and immune function. Chimpanzees, our closest living evolutionary relatives, are exemplary study subjects for unravelling these physiological interactions, as they form dynamic social relationships ranging from affiliative (e.g., social bonds) to competitive (e.g., social status). This project investigated the interactions of social relationships, hormone function, and immune health in the Ngogo chimpanzees of Kibale National Park, Uganda, the largest community of wild chimpanzees ever described.

The investigators collected observations of chimpanzee behavior combined with health assessments and biological samples with which to analyze hormones (e.g., cortisol, testosterone), biomarkers of immune activity (e.g., neopterin), and viral infections. Over four years of study, the investigators produced an integrative dataset containing more than 1,500 hours of observational data (including records of social behavior and GPS tracks of chimpanzee travel distances), 680 urine samples analyzed for a variety of hormones and biomarkers, and 100 noninvasive measurements of chimpanzee body temperature.

Although data analysis is ongoing, this project has already yielded evidence for physiological links between social behavior and immune function in wild chimpanzees. Notably, as reported in Co-Investigator Negrey’s doctoral dissertation, the investigators found that the steroid hormones testosterone and cortisol, which are thought to modulate immune function, are correlated with the occurrence of status-relevant behaviors. Furthermore, the investigators found evidence that reproductive hormones mediate trade-offs between reproductive effort and immune function. For instance, during periods of acute illness, innate immune activity and energy mobilization increased while concentrations of reproductive hormones decreased, presumably in support of immune function.

Furthermore, in a collaborative project with multiple long-term chimpanzee research projects, the investigators analyzed simultaneous outbreaks of severe respiratory disease in Kibale’s chimpanzees, which were caused by two different viruses of human origin. These results underline the threat of infectious disease to great ape conservation, given the frequency with which human-chimpanzee disease transmission may occur.

Finally, the investigators validated a newly modified method for noninvasively estimating the body temperature of large-bodied primates from fecal deposits. The investigators were able to generate rare data on chimpanzee body temperature, demonstrating this method’s usefulness for the study of chimpanzee behavioral ecology. For instance, the investigators found that chimpanzee mating effort corresponds to increased body temperature, thereby capturing metabolic costs associated with male-male competition.

This project united a diverse team of scientists working on three continents and provided opportunities for the training of various research personnel in field and laboratory methods. In addition, the project’s results were helpful in implementing conservation-oriented policy changes at relevant field sites. Finally, the researchers’ presence in Kibale National Park supported local education and anti-poaching efforts critical to the protection of chimpanzees and other endangered species.
